A roguelike with a good sense of progression, courtesy of an upgrade system that moves with you as you die. Unlike a lot of other games, you'll always restart with a little more power or abilities and a better chance of surviving longer each time.  The trait system is really interesting, and balances between good and bad enough that sometimes you just have to chose something like being farsighted in order to get the class you want.

I don't typically write reviews, but Rogue Legacy for me is going to be an exception. Ill start off with the pros and cons and then give some of my final thoughts.   But first, I just logged into the game to play one run through and HOLY CRAP I BEAT THE GAME! Finally!!  Pros: +Fast paced, hack and slash, dungeon crawl +Simple mob combat +Very fun spells +Strategic and challenging boss fights +After you defeat a boss, the door unlocks so you can do a unique challenge fight +RPG elements (item upgrades, rune upgrades, castle upgrades) +Very wide character variety +Deaths bring you a selection from three random characters +Randomized character traits +Randomized levels after each death +Quirky and a fun story line +Weight - Yes, weight. It brings a special element and challenge. You can't just unlock the best gear and wear it. You have to make sure your character upgrades accordingly. +Difficulty starts at a standard. You can control it by adding runes, which I've found also gives you new and unseen levels to the dungeon +168 hours played and I just beat the final boss. I still have so many upgrades and blue prints to find. +In that, extremely high replay value  Cons: -Finding later tier (tier 4 and 5) gear is very difficult -Once you unlock enough upgrades to your castle, the grind can feel tedious. This doesn't happen for a very long time, though. -There are very annoying occurances at times due to bridge placement. I.E. when trying to escape a level by jumping up to a bridge and activating it, only to have the hit cause your character to fly into the upper room and then back to the lower room. Causing it to reset. I'm not sure if this is meant to be a challenge to the player or just poor placement.  This game will always be a favorite of mine. The control you have to either farm for gold or challenge yourself to get blueprints for gear, is amazing. I find it really fun to have a choice of random characters and I love all of the unique traits they can come with. Whether you are looking for a dungeon crawl to play casually, or challenge yourself with hardcore settings, this game can fit anyone's arsenal of games.  5/5

Let me begin by saying that this game was truly a welcome surprise, I expected not to like it and boy did it prove me wrong...  So, what is it ? Is it really a rogue like ??? oh sure, in a sense... I mean there is no real save and you restart your adventures in a procedurally created dungeon every time... on the other hand not really because you actually do improve each time over and thats a fundamental no-no for rogue likes....  At the end of the day its a hybrid, that will appeal more to non rogue-like fanatics, rather than the true fans of that genre.  The thing is that if you look past all that, its a truly fast paced, fun-filled plat-former that will make you swear, cry and smile every-time you give it a go and believe me you will give it a go and another and another and so on... its so compelling to just try to do a bit better each time.  The main concept of the game is that each time you die you can start over with one of your descendants all of whom carry over the abilities of their ancestors (and their flaws). So you gather money with each run and but abilities and equipment and each generation is a bit stronger - mind you you cant keep your gold (or at least most of it) between runs, since you need pay death each time you enter the dungeon (except in cases where you have found a special item that you turn on instead of gold).  A similarity to rogue like games is that it starts out very hard and that will frustrate most players (but you will come back for more). However as you progress and improve it becomes easier and I must say (this is one of my grievances with it) after a point it becomes, perhaps too easy.  The bosses are somewhat easy (with the exception of the four special bosses that are insanely hard - but those are not necessary to finish the game) and each new play-through increases the difficult (ala Dark Souls New Game +1 ect).  One thing that ticked me off, which becomes apparent when you master it, is that it is actually short and it really makes you yearn for more.... perhaps with some expansion or dlc but you would like to do more much more (and this is another point where it differs dramatically with true rogue-likes).  The graphics are pix-elated but beautiful and the retro style suits it so well, the music can get a tad annoying at times but then again its very reminiscent of 8-bit era game music.  Overall I have to say I loved the game and I truly wish it had more to offer, but it doesn't. Is it worth playing in spite of that ? Hell yes - its so much fun....  But after 5 play-throughs and all achievements equipment the only thing left was the special bosses. I did spent the time to kill one of them but its for the true hardcores... perhaps I may go back and try them again for the achievements alone, but at this stage there isn't a lot of re-playability.  Again, regardless of any shortcoming I described, its so much fun and totally worth it (which is why its a bit disappointing at the end).

At first, this game is very entertainting. The combat is fast-paced, you can upgrade your character however you want, and the character descendants are often humorous.  But after a few hours, it gets *extremely* repetetive. The game's hook is that you will die, and you WILL indeed die A LOT. I thought games had evolved past the 3-decade old idiocy of being 'touched' by anything hurts you, but apparently this game didn't get the memo. Often you are surrounded by half a dozen monsters, which means dozens of projectiles flying at you and even more chances to get 'touched' by monsters. Ranged attacks would help greatly but mana is so limited for even the most basic of ranged attacks that you can't rely on it. So you're forced to melee most of the time against projectiles flying all over the screen. It makes for a very frustrating experience. So you die. And then die some more.  Dying often could be forgiveable if you're progressing. However, in this game, you are literally playing the same level over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over. It gets old fast. The only way to progress is to grind the same level repeatedly for gold, while memorizing enemies. But with limited HP and each hit taking so much HP away, not to mention the annoyance of accidental 'touches' as described previously, you'll die often no matter what you do.  The upgrade system seemed really great at first, but every time you upgrade your character the price of all other upgrades increases. Essentially the carrot in front of your nose is being moved farther and farther every time.  Not only that, but every time you die, you have to give up all your gold before restarting the level. So you have 1000 gold and spend 500 on an upgrade, with the next cheapest upgrade at 510? Too bad, you have to completely waste the rest. Idiotic beyond belief. After a while, all the upgrades become so expensive that if you don't farm thousands of gold before an accidental death, you have to give it all up and you just made 0 progress. After a few hours, the game expects you to play perfectly, or you won't progress at all.  I was indeed getting really good at the end of my play time and really memorizing all the enemies and how they moved. But then I took a step back and realized that I wasn't having fun any more. Because of the extreme repetition in this game and the frustrating nature of combat, I would certainly give this game a DO NOT BUY. I bought this on sale for $2.99 and wish I could get my money back.

This is a good rogue like game that has an interesting progression system.   This progression system is really one of the key reason why I put so many hours into this game. Most rogue like games have perma death. Where if you lose thats it, its done you start from the beginning. Personally I did not like the idea of perma death in my games. I like to feel like I am working towards something and not losing everything just to try to do it again. With this said, many people who like rogue like games will disagree whole heartily with my decision and I understand that. Well with this game people get a little bit of both worlds.   This game has perma death and progression. Each character that goes into that death trap of a castle will eventually die but his or her's gold will be sent to their child where he or she can spend it on upgrades to their castle (that supplies skills, armory, stats etc) and to buy armor, accessories and even lock the previous dungeon so you can attempt it again. Then that child will die and send it's money to the next child and so on. So people get their perma death and progression all in one.   The gameplay is fun with platformer elements to it as well as rpg. Its a 2d side scroller where you go around in a randomly generated dungeon looting for gold, trying to survive and fighting bosses. Thanks to the option to lock the previous dungeon you can keep retrying the bosses again and again, without searching for the boss door. Which is nice because the bosses can be extremely hard if your not prepared. Also the dungeon itself is hard as well and you will find that it will take many attempts before finding the boss doors.   So overall, the progression system as well as the gameplay makes for an addicting game. With this said, their are a few issues I have with the game. When your character dies you get a selection of three (maybe four) randomly generated characters to choose from. All of these characters have different classes, special attacks and/or different qualities. Although the qualities like vertigo can really mess with you, most of the other qualities are forgettable after a while but it does add another element to the game at times. The random generated abilities on the other hand, were for the most part useless because most of the classes (except maybe mage and spell sword) had very little Mp to work with. I found that the normal attacks were sufficient in getting me through the dungeons. It could have really helped if the characters had a bigger Mp pool to work with and maybe some different spells and abilities.   Overall, good game with a few issues with the characters abilities, still very fun to play and has a game plus mode so good replayability as well.

The concept of this game is excellent, but once you get up to (and past) the first boss, it all feels kind of pointless:  1. Everytime you purchase an upgrade the other upgrades become 10 gold more expensive. So if you have a bad run, you spend your gold so its not wasted (the game takes your money when you re-enter the castle)-- and then the expensive upgrades that you DO want are just that much further out of your reach.  2. The randomly generated castle is an artificial thing meant to extend the game's lifespan. You can learn about the (small) handfull of enemies in each area, but you'll spend 90% of your time in the first two zones, over and over, just trying to progress. Progression is stunted even further by the game's general concept. You get just a LITTLE bit further each time, or the castle generates a room full of spikes and you take 75% of your health in damage before getting anywhere. Better get used to that first room, mate, because those four candlestick holders and that chair are always gonna be there for you to hit every. Single. Time.  3. Bosses are bullet-hell creatures. Given this game's 'tough but fair' philosophy and how easy it is to die, this was completely out of left field. The sudden difficulty ramp when it comes to killing any of the bosses will be like crashing into a brick wall, and made even worse if you're using a keyboard. The game only has five bosses, and rightly so considering how it all works, but the sudden spike in difficulty is not only unwelcome but punishing to the unwary gamer. I like difficulty so it's not a cakewalk, but I don't apprieciate having almost no chance at all. This is a cartoonish platformer, not Dark Souls.  4. No difficulty adjustment.   5. You can't use a mouse on any of the menus, which just FEELS wierd.  =-=-=-=-=  Don't get me wrong, I liked this game a lot when I first got it, but I'll never be able to finish it. The constant grind-grind-grind for gold with almost nothing to show for it 80% of the time, coupled with the VERY difficult boss fights make this game a little too hard for a casual gamer like myself. Games are about fun to me, and if my game becomes an endless loop with no progress it stops being fun. :(

Its addicting!  Now, your heirs come in all shapes and sizes such as midgets that can fit through secret tunnels, giants that are harder to dodge with but have a giant sword swing arc, colorblinds, heroes that fart when you jump... haha, theres a lot of 'genetic' traits that your heirs can have - some good, some bad!  There are classes such as the high damage, speedy but frail Hokage, the tank Barbarian that can use a Fus Ro Dah shout to knock away enemies and projectiles, a mage with massive mana pool who gets mana back when you kill foe and a bunch others. Note: I posted an update at the end. I wrote my original review after a few hours of gameplay. The update is after 18 hours and changes my opinion on the game somewhat.   This is a really fun game. I've been hooked on it the last two or three days. You start with one hero and you venture off into the castle. The layout is randomized each time you play. You fight enemies, leap over spikes, the usual platform game challenges. I don't really like platform games, but this has become an exception. I'm not very skilled with these types of games and my character dies A LOT. But every time you run through the game, you collect money, runes, and equipment to build yourself up. You also gain levels which appears to boost hp/mp.   When you lose, you start again, purchasing your upgrades, then venturing into a new castle totally unlike the one you last explored. There's an option to lock them down (for a 40% cut in gold intake), but it means that when you go back in any treasure chests you opened are already used, so you have to explore deeper to find new treasure. Each time you start again, you choose a new hero, which can range from spell casters to strong melee to heavy armor/high hp, to low hp spelunkers that reveal chests on the map. It's a nice variety. Also, some of the characters have status effects like 'colorblind' where the levels are black and white, which can add challenge by making it more difficult to separate some enemies from the backgrounds. There is also near-sightedness which creates a blur on the screen outside a certain range of vision. There's even one that makes you play the game upside-down. I tried that one once and avoid it at all costs now.   I think the main draw of this game is that you can load this up with the intention of killing 20-30 minutes and it's still fun 2 hours later. It can be frustrating though. With randomized layouts, some rounds are going to be significantly more difficult than others. Fairy Chest rooms are the worst, sometimes having rules that just don't make sense like 'no jumping' when the entire room is a series of platforms over spikes. Even if you run through the spikes, you still need to jump out of them at the end. Maybe there are runes to overcome this that I will find later.   As you upgrade your character, the gold cost of upgrades naturally increases. I'd imagine at some point this cost will become excessive, as I am already struggling to bring in enough gold for some upgrades as it is. The worst part is that you have to use your gold or lose it before reentering the castle. You have to give up any remaining gold you have to enter, so if the cheapest upgrade you have access to is 650 gold and you have 640, goodbye all 640 gold. You can reduce this toll but it costs a lot to upgrade and it appears the max is probably going to be a 30% reduction. I've only done 1/5 reductions. They don't really seem worth it, so I've been investing in more useful upgrades.   The music is good, the layouts are interesting, the game is challenging. There isn't much in terms of story. You uncover short journals as you progress. It's fine that the game is lacking in story, however. It's not the point of the game. It keeps you going with the action non-stop (except for selecting your upgrades).   Lastly, boss battles seem disproportionately difficult for the rest of the game. I'm level 60 or so now and it's getting pretty easy to clear the castle (even for someone who is terrible at these types of games), but the bosses are much much stronger than anything else you encounter.  Update: After playing for 18 hours, I've pretty much burned out on this game. All I do at this point is run dungeons over and over and over collecting money to spend on upgrades, so that hopefully I'll one day beat bosses outside the first area (the castle). The costs on everything keep going up, so it's an incredibly slow grind to unlock the incredibly large amount of upgrades. On top of that, after 18 hours I'm only level 150. I've read that the level cap is just over 500. Assuming that exp to level up increases per level, it would take 60+ hours to reach level 500. That is way too much of a time investment into grinding. I never minded putting large amounts of hours into games like Final Fantasy 7, for example, because at least you're progressing through a story at the same time. Rogue Legacy has no story.   Do I still recommend this game? Sure. I did enjoy it for 18 hours. That's a nice turnaround on a $5 game (on sale). If you're looking for a game you'll finish, however, this one probably isn't it.

I love games that punish me for not playing perfectly. Things like Super Meat Boy, Spelunky, Super Hexagon, and Limbo are some of my favorites. And when I started Rogue Legacy, it felt like heading back down into the mines of Spelunky. But as I kept playing, that changed a bit. This game is hard on you, but it's not unforgiving because, even when you fail, you make progress.  I hesitate to call this a rogue-like because it moves almost all progression from the game to the meta-game; you don't power up at all (except for one or two rare exceptions) while you're playing, and when you do, it's permanent. Contrast that with Spelunky, FTL, Binding of Isaac, Desktop Dungeon, etc., where failure means a complete restart, and you get a much different experience - a nicer, kinder experience.  This rogueish-like (rogue-likeish? rogue-like-like?) gameplay is perfectly complimented by smooth platforming mechanics, very solid controls (though I would recommend a gamepad), a good variety of enemies, and a great soundtrack. Toss in the descendent and trait gimmicks and this you've got yourself a well-designed, highly replayable, very polished experience.

(I haven't tried it with keyboard and mouse, 2D sidescrollers aren't really built for that I think.)  * The level progression is pretty much perfectly balanced. You will level up after more or less every run, just enough to make you notice the difference but not so much that it gets too easy.  * The rooms are reoccuring, so you get to recognise most of them and learn how to best handle them. But they may contain different enemies at different times, and the order in which you find them are procedurally generated.  * You will probably want to grind some levels at some point, having trouble with a boss or something. But it rarely, if ever, feels like grinding. The different classes, spells, and special traits helps keep things interesting, especially combined with the fact that you will earn levels fairly quickly. (In the later stages of the game I usually earned 3-5 levels per run.)  * You might think it is too hard during the first 30-60 minutes or so, especially if you happen to run into the most challening rooms from the start. But then you start learning the controls and how enemies move, and you start leveling up, and then it is just great and addictive fun!  * I bought this on sale, along with like 50 other games or something. I haven't even tried the other games yet - I just could not stop playing this one. I almost wish I had paid full price, just to support the creators.   * When I'm writing this, nearly 10% of all Rogue Legacy-players have the achievement for completing the game - twice. That should say something about something, I guess. :)

BUY THIS INSTEAD OF FTL!  Top says it all. This game is pretty much everything FTL is not. Brutally challenging but...FUN. That's F U N, what's that spell? Fun!  RL is considered to be a Rogue Lite, as the game allows the player to gain experience/gold to spend on tech tree upgrades or armor upgrades. It uses an RNG to generate the castle map and enemy layouts and does create some creative ways to kill you. The upside? You can HIT the enemies 100% of the time! This simple idea, whose origins began BEFORE Super Mario Bros. and Castlevania... and somehow... escaped the two guys that made FTL is -I must say- pretty darn satisfying. Who knew that an attack system based on simple spatial awareness could be so...intuitive and enjoyable.  Also when enemies attack you, you can...dodge.  'Dodge?' you say, 'Sounds like some fool's flim-flamery to me!'  I assure you dear sir, or madam, that it is entirely genuine. When an enemy attacks the player's character you use the controller to move out of the way of the incoming projectile and thus, negate any damage.  'And what of these enemies? I suppose in the interim of this electronic experience I'm forced to grind these scallywags.'  You may sir, you...may. You see, the point of Rogue Legacy is exploration, loot chests, and boss battles. You may kill them and receive a modest reward or avoid them entirely. Unlike FTL, the enemies are an obstacle not a resource.  'Well I say, this is starting to sound like a rummy good time.'  I assure you it is. The graphics are pixel artwork and actual care has been taken to achieve a certain asthetic appeal. No longer do you shamble blobby vaguely human crew members about a static background (like FTL) but a valiant knight, mage, assassin and many more characters each with their own playstyle, pros and cons.  The story is a simple one, but it actually exists (unlike FTL). You play an adventurer searching a castle to find a lost prince and slay the monsters that dwell within. Everytime the character dies, decendants are generated to pick up the quest. Exploration reveals notes by the lost prince that shed light on the story, answering questions and eluding to new questions.  Death comes swiftly for any faint-hearted adventurer but the gold you have collected is used to help increase stats like health, mana, weapon and magic damage. Or, use it to buy better gear and weapons for the sons and daughters that come after. The game is filled with dead-pan humor and a lot of the messages and even some player traits will produce a gaffaw or two.  One minor criticism are the controls are a bit on the floaty side. Your character lacks weight and also the hit boxes can be a bit...vague. I don't believe the game has true analog. The player can only run at full speed which can and does get frustrating at times. Though these aren't enough to detract from the game, in this humble critic's opinion.  Pick it up in the steam shop. Full price and you'll still be satisfied, catch it on sale and it's a steal.

Throw away any of your preconceptions of the 'roguelike' genre. Although this game shares some of the basic shapes with that awkwardly named set, Rogue Legacy is such a unique take on the genre that it hardly deserves to be lumped in with the rest of them.  This is far closer to a Castlevania or Ghosts-n-Goblins platformer, although it broadens the platforming genre with aspects of the roguelike (permadeath, randomly generated maps, rapid character iteration). It also throws in a dash of clever character progression in the form of upgrades to your Keep. Various different fundamental upgrades ('Health Up', 'Unlock New Character Class', 'Improve Negotiation', etc.) will create a branching upgrade tree that is graphically represented by the growth and extension of the character's home base.  And when I say 'character', I should really say 'family'. Each time your avatar dies, the battle is carried on by one of his or her children, each of whom are saddled with traits ranging from good (Strong arms = improved knockback), to bad (Vertigo = The screen is vertically flipped), to ugly (Irritable Bowel Syndrome). Did I mention amusing?  The whole package comes together with clever level design (you'd hardly believe that this is really 'random'), awesome visuals, challenging and varied enemies, and a level of 'sheen' rarely seen from a relatively small Indie studio.  Recommended, all around. Even if you don't know (or like) what a 'roguelike' is... This is so much more.

This is not a forgiving game for those that just rush through platformers/bullet-hell games, or just jump at enemies to attack them without planning. You will get crushed, hard and often, and that it will be very frustrating.  If you take the time to approach each level properly, it is a challenge worth conquering. The randomly generated levels (except mini-boss and final boss levels) and maps and loot and extras means that it's an almost endless number of different play-throughs each time. This time, when I approached it with a different mind-set, I got hooked on this game in a bad way. I was playing it an hour or two every other night for a month, and finally starting making progress in the game, to the point where I just finished it last night. (Of course, you can jump right back in and continue playing in '+' mode (same format, difficulty cranked up), but I needed a break.)  Outside actually playing the levels and defeating the monsters/bosses/traps, the framework around this game gives you LOTS of variations on how to play it.  Multiple classes, multiple stat/class upgrades, multiple genetic traits (both positive & negative), multiple armour/weapon slots, multiple upgrades for those items, multiple runes for those items...there are so many different ways to craft your character.   Finally, there is a lot of humourous touches in this game that show through in little places everywhere.  I would highly recommend this game, but only if you have patience and perseverance.

Wow, rogue legacy. If you're looking for a good time sync of a game that will leave you wanting to play more as soon as possible you've found one. The castle Is separated into four different areas, The Castle, The Garden, The Attic and The Darkness (or The Basement if you prefer) each one varying in difficulty and with each their own unique boss, which once defeated is not accessible by any other family descendants. As you progress through the game with your many different characters you will slowly learn more an more about the story of the castle that your family is trying to conquer through rare journal rooms which will give you a small bit of information each time found.  The way you will progress throughout this game is through gold. Now once you set off into the castle the gatekeeper will take all of your descendants unspent gold (which can be upgraded so you can keep some of it upon entry). Once this is done you will have to hit everything that you can see to gain gold for upgrades weather it be chairs, chandeliers, mushrooms or monsters which at the start can be quite the challenge in of itself. Once dead the next of kin will inherent all of the money earned and be able to spend it on upgrades armor or enchanted runes that will give you awesome abilities. I think I should go a bit more into detail about the bloodlines. 90% of the time, like the real life, your characters wont be perfect each having something wrong with them. I find this to be one of the key things that keep me interested in this game as each different descendant will mix the game up more each time. While some will have illnesses that are not to uncommon to real life, other such thing may be quite weird and wacky such as the fear of chickens. I definitely find this element of the game good as not to make the game feel like much of a grind as it should. I also feel as if it adds some personality to each hero/heroine you play as each time, not making everyone the same and in perfect health like many so other games do.   While I do love this game ever so much it does have downsides that need to be taken into account. Some people do have this problem, some don't (personally I don't) but using a controller seems like the optimal way to play, as from what I've heard the keyboard layout is quite uncomfortable. Also, although it is randomly generated to an extent you will be getting used to the different rooms of the castle as rooms can (and most likely will be) used more than once in a run. This means that once you've learned how to deal with a type of rooms it can take away some of the challenge of the game. The final thing I'd say that is bad about is towards the end of the upgrade trees, it is one hell of a grind at that point potentially costing over 15 thousand gold for one health upgrade. This can really become quite ridiculous as I feel you can loose a lot of motivation at that point.  So my final words are that I find it to be a good very purchase at full price (£12) and would recommend that you get it as soon as humanly possible. Damn, it's a lot of fun.

I love platformers, especially retro-inspired ones or ones with roglue-like elements. Most of my Steam library is made up of these types of games. They are my favorite genre. This game seems really great when you first start, it appears that there is so much to unlock and so much to explore, but the reality is that it never begins to fill one tenth of the potential it appears to have at the start of the game. Random level design can be great, just look at Spelunky, but the random designs in Rogue Legacy too often result in just plain bad layouts, platform and enemy layouts that seem unfair and are impossible to traverse without being hit, regardless of player skill. The other big problem with this game is that leveling up your character seems to have very little effect on his effectiveness in the dungeon. Even after 20+ hours, it's still very easy to die without progressing far at all. On top of this, the game punishes you for dying by making all your skills most expensive to purchase every time you enter the dungeon, whether your trip is successful or not. You grind and grind but your hard work never seems to pay off and this ultimately leads to a general feeling disappointment when you realize how shallow the game really is.   So what do you get when you put it all together? A platformer with bad level design, lots of really annoying enemies, and a character that's continuously weak and prone to dying. This game is hard for all the wrong reasons and none of the right ones. If you want some great Metroidvania action, skip this game and pick up Castle in the Darkness, it's less than half the price and more than ten times the game.

Congratulations to Rogue Legacy for missing the entire point of Rogue.  Rogue and its derivatives were one of the very few games where leveling systems made sense by virtue of using it as a resource that you needed to manage and by taking away your levels when you lost. Rogue Legacy manages to bork it up by making the leveling system not only PERMANENT, but completely external to the game play itself. There is no level resource to manage in each playthrough. Your equipment is set in stone from the beginning of each game. And each time you die, you get a little stronger.  So the way you succeed in this game is by DYING. What you learned from each death is much less important than the permanent +1 to strength you're going to get when you do. In fact, this makes dying DESIRABLE.  Hey game, if you're going to give me all these classes and levels eventually anyway, why are you making me go through the work of unlocking them? And while we're at it, how about you just set the difficulty to a reasonable level from the very start?  Oh yeah, that would violate the sacred tenet of gaming known as the 'leveling system.'  On top of that, the level layouts will deny you things by virtue of you having brought the wrong runes or by what random traits your new character has. Then when you pick those things you need, the RNG can just as easily not require them of you. What's the lesson here? '♥♥♥♥ you,' apparently.  But unfair BS is kind of the name of the game. You'll be put into plenty of unfair situations simply by virtue of how far you can see on your screen. You'll be put into expansive rooms where everything has projectile weaponry and fires at you all at once, but the game thinks this is okay because it has this mess of off screen indicators for you to try to parse. Is the high or low bullet going to enter the screen from the left first? Oops, never mind, that one top indicator was actually a stack of four arcing bullets indicators coming from an enemy you haven't yet seen. And god help you if your character views the world upside down.  You will spend hours and hours of unnecessary grinding in this game for no reason, and when you do succeed, you have no idea how much was your own improvement and how much was just the fact that your stats are so much higher than when you first started. It's especially weird that the developer thinks this is somehow related to Rogue. Rogue isn't the best game in the world, but it works because there is no permanent progression. Rogue Legacy reverses that, and tries to convince you it's because it wants everyone to beat the game eventually. But if you want to make a game where everyone wins, then just making losing impossible. Don't give me more stats until I win and then pretend it was me all along.  Rogue Legacy makes you grind out thousands of deaths to reach the difficulty level you should've had in the first place. It gives you so many crutches and helping hands along the way that by the end, it's patently obvious to you that your win has been gift-wrapped with a big red bow. And when the game tries to come back at the end to give you a pat on the back for doing such a good job... it's pretty disingenuous. Downright insulting, really.  If this was to be Rogue's legacy, I'd advocate for more birth control.

Rogue Legacy is an interesting take on the 2D hack'n slash and some of the core aspects of roguelikes (even though RL is not an actual roguelike)  Every death is an opportunity to upgrade your stats and start again. At first i was worried that this would lead to just a pure grind, where i would farm gold until i had enough upgrades to beat the bosses. But Rogue Legacy is more clever than that, and manages to make every run satisfying for itself, a good platform/hack'n slash gameplay that reward good players with more loot. That way, you enjoy each run, but progressively you get ready for the boss encounters, which are the main steps of progression.  On the whole, the progression is really enjoyable. The game is very good at teaching you how to be better, by introducing new ennemies regularly. It's interesting to see that, at the beginning, the most dangerous areas of the dungeon seems full of unbeatable monsters, whereas once you've got some experience, you understand they are just evolutions of the enemies you've encountering before.  A negative point though: the upgrade system is not as flexible as would like it to be, or as it seemed at the beginning. By the mid-game it was becoming clear that i have to build/upgrade in a specific way if you want to be the most efficient. And that means many of the classes tend to be very weak, which is a bit sad when the game is advertised as you having to play with the random characters. In practice, you will understand that some classes are better than the others and favor theses ones.  The game will take about 20h to finish, and doesn't overstay its welcome. It was getting a bit repetitive in the end, and I'm glad it wasn't longer.  For people who really enjoy it and want more, the game offers unlimited replayability, in the form of infinite 'New Game +' mode, where each new game plus increases monster difficulty and rewards. However, the game will not offer you new stuff, just the same monsters with increased stats, so it will just be a game of grinding stats for your character.

I don't even know where to begin to start telling you about how awesome this game is.  This game is nintendo hard, at least when you first start out. There are no saves, no reloads. As your classes evolve they unlock new abilities. Couple all of this with the fact that castles are randomly generated and you have a game with TONS of replayability.   Now that I've told you about all of the fun stuff here's a list of things that could have been implemented to make the game far less grindy and even better. In order to progress you need to unlock gear/abilities/runes and the only way to do this is with gold. Skills and items are INCREIDBLY expensive and earning gold is slow. Every time your hero dies and you choose a descendent to take over, charon steals all of your gold when you go back into the castle. So when you are first starting out, if you don't earn enough gold to unlock anything, you'll lose it all when you go back in the castle. You can actually buy skills where you can bargain with the gate keeper - they are very expensive and the max amount of gold you can retain (when fully skillled) is only 50%. Rogue Legacy is awesome. A short description if you somehow don't know. It's an action platformer game in a castle whose layout is randomly generated. You run around swording dudes getting gold and loot. The cool bit is when you die you pick a new character from three choices, each of whom are given a random class, spell, and traits that could be benefits or drawback. Each character requires you to adjust your playstyle to match. You then have the opportunity to spend the gold you earned on character upgrades (these apply to every future character you get), new and better gear, and runes (these confer abilities like adding up to 6 air jumps) which can be swapped out for each character. Spend what you've got since the reaper will take all your gold (this can be reduced to half through upgrasdes) on your way into the castle, which is given a totally new layout.  I've spent about sixty hours in the game now. The thing that hooks me the most is that Rogue Legacy is one of the best playing games I've ever played. The controls are as responsive as they come, on par with a Super Meatboy (without the momentum model), but the way it controls includes a lot of gameplay nicities. You can move while swinging your sword, but damage is done when an enemy collides with your sword, not when you push the button. So for faster classes you can play fighting game style footsies with enemies by swinging, running forward to poke a dude then dashing back before he hits you. This can be further enhanced by character traits like flexible, which allows you to change directions while swinging. You can even dash in a direction your not facing giving you complete control over your mobility.  When you combine runes, classes, traits, and gear (some of which might favor spellcaster, or have added effects like +2 air jumps), every time you go into the castle you're going in with a different playstyle. The game then has massive difficulty scaling through its new game plus features and remix bosses. I've never beat a remix boss (they are so hard), but have beaten the game on NG+++++. I will unquestionably recommend this game. You'll get an amazing game with tons of replay value, its definitely worth the fifteen dollar ask.

Let me start by saying this, in order to get anywhere in Rogue Legacy, you have to die, and die you will. In Rouge Legacy you control your children in a long line of sometimes afflicted family members who are trying to atone for the past sin of your ancestor. You'll brave a castle filled with a number of powerful bosses in different areas, all ready to send you to a very easily earned death, though you'll have to find them in the castle first. Each time you die, you get to select one of your three children, all of different size, class, gender, and other factors that can affect gameplay.  While this game does require a certain level of skill, in the end, it's a grind, but a fun grind if you can enjoy this sort of thing. Your character grows by leaving all of the gold they've gathered in the castle to their children, which they can spend on stat upgrades, equipment, and special runes that can give you abilities. Be warned though, until a certain upgrade is earned, you'll loose all of your unspent gold when entering the castle again (there's a skill that when a large sum of gold is invested into, you can keep upwards to 50% of your gold when going in the castle).  However, once one of your children decides to brave the castle, they'll find it isn't what their dad or mom went through. The castle randomizes its layout each time you enter, unless you pay to have the layout locked down at the cost of potential rewards (good if you decide to work on fighting a boss). This can definitely keep you interested while you throw your children into harm's way just so their children after them can have a few more hitpoints to survive the next area.  All in all, I've had a lot of fun with this game, and still play a bit on NG+ ever now and then. It may not be worth 15 bucks to a lot of people (though I think it is, but was lucky enough to get it as a gift), but if you see it on sale and want a Rogue-lite Castlevania-esque game, pick it up!

The first few times through you are going to die, and you are going to die a lot. But with each new attempt through you are going to make it farther, such is the case with every roguelike. The learning curve here is right on track, you learn the enemies' patterns and what to expect when you enter each new room. After about an hour of playtime you start to think 'I could use a little more,' and you find yourself a movement upgrade, as well as another class with some extra stat padding, and it gets a little better. You start working your way through the castle and eventually you beat your first boss, and it gets a lot better. You upgrade more, earn more classes, and you get hooked.  What this game has is a perfect rate of progression. Your skill and your upgrades combine to create a great experience, where skill is always needed even at higher levels, but the upgrades keep it from feeling stale and monotonous. In this game you are always going through the same basic steps. The rooms don't change much, you'll use all your classes many times, but it never feels the same. Every time through feels fresh, it is diverse where other roguelikes become repetitive. This is what Rogue Legacy offers.  If you are reading this review and have come this far, I would say your interest is great enough to warrant a purchase of this game. If you like character progression but a challenge at the same time, similar to the brand of Demon's Souls and Dark Souls, then you owe it to yourself to try this out.

In fact, it makes dying feel less painful, because you know that every death (usually) leads to a little improvement in your next character.

I thought I knew what to expect after reading the description and watching the trailer. The first impression it made on me was that it would be a fun and quick little way to kill some time. I figured it would be a casual game. Boy was I wrong.  Pros: This game offers just enough challenge to keep me hitting the proverbial try again button while saying 'I know I can do better'. The random level generation works! So far I have never felt like I was just replaying the same thing (unless I wanted to ;) ).   Key mapping is also a great feature. I like being able to customize what keys control what movements.  I really like having the ability to re-enter the exact same castle layout. It is really handy for if I died too quickly, or I came across a spot that my current character couldn't enter. In fact, it's actually nice to see that the physical and personality quirks that each character has, not only adds some neat little dynamic to the next playthrough, but also can have a genuine use. While it's fun to run around as a gigantic barbarian, smashing all in my way repeatedly with my sword, sometimes, to access little hidden areas, I need to be the tiniest of men, or women, and I love that!  Another thing I like IS just the variety of character options! With so many classes, it's fun to play around with the various randomly generated character options. Even though they aren't given to you at the beginning, I feel it's actually better that way. I liked working to earn the coin to unlock them. However, I will admit that it was almost painful sometimes, when chosing what to unlock.  I really enjoy reading the journal entries and I can't wait to find out more of the back story. While it is agonizing to have to hand so much coin over to Charon at times, I understand the necessity. I think that the game did a great job explaining why it is present. An unlockable that you can get later on is really nice though and I admit I don't feel bad about haggling with Charon to keep some of my hard earned gold. (Honestly, best job in this game is Charon's XD )  The sound track is phenominal. In fact, I have actually started the game and just left it running so I could listen.  I'm a really big fan of pixel art and I have to say Rogue Legacy did a beautiful job with it. The characters and environments are nicely detailed and look fantastic.   Cons: I was led to believe that, while I could pick a new character from a selection of three options, I could also go back and pick one of my previous characters. I don't know, maybe I missed something, but I honestly thought I could go back and pick a character I had already played as. I understand why this is not an actual feature though, because it could be abused and defeat the purpose of playing as the 'child' of your now dead character. Still though, it was a little disappointing when I went back to play as Sir Taco II, only to find I couldn't.  Some of the descriptions on items that you can unlock, are either unclear, or too vague. I have used the gold I earned to purchase power ups that ended up not doing what I thought they would. For example, I was led to believe that through purchasing a certain power-up, I would be able to fly (aka pressing the action button would allow me to 'fly' upwards), if for a very limited amount of time. In truth, what I did was stay in place in the air for several seconds (which didn't help me when I was falling after attempting to make too large a jump, thinking that I would be able 'flap my wings' to reach it).  While most of the upgrades and power-ups boost general stats, some of them unlock other branches, which may contain playable classes. The problem is, sometimes the branch unlocked doesn't make any sense compared to what unlocked it. Unfortunately, I found myself having to put coins into things I didn't necessarily want, just so I could unlock a new branch and hopefully find a new playable class, or something else useful (which means I would have to just keep throwing myself at castle after castle for more gold, that I could spend on the new thing). Considering how difficult it can be to accumulate large sums of money, I didn't really like having to spend it on something I didn't feel a need for.  I think that while the enemies' increase in difficulty as you level up, works, the steep rise in how much it cost to unlock things seems kind of unfair. Especially compared to each coins individual worth. Sometimes I feel less like an adventuring hero out for glory and vengeance, and more like a peasant struggling to pay the resident lord.    Even though it may seem like I have a lot more negative criticism for the game, I truly do love it. This game can, through great will power (rarely frustration) on my part, be a casual quick time killer. However, I find myself coming back to it again and again because I keep telling myself 'I can make it this time', or I'm enticed by the promise of a new layout.  Needless to say my death count, or rather 'portrait count' is quite extensive.   I whole heartedly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys a nice pixel-visual and musical accompanyment; and has the patience to die a thousand deaths.

It is difficult to begin a review of this game that accurately captures both its awesomeness and appeal. Fans of hack-and-slash games, dungeon crawlers, and RPG's alike will find themselves pouring hours and hours into this game. You explore a massive castle, with each new area revealing new enemies and evolutions of previous ones. You scour the castle for gold to upgrade your abilities in order to defeat the bosses in each area. When you die, you keep your gold, and your next character spends it on permanent upgrades like health and damage, new equipment (which you must find blueprints for in the castle) and 'runes' to attach to your equipment (which you also find in the castle, but must complete a challenge to obtain). However, you must spend your gold wisely, as you lose it all upon re-entering the castle! This is a great example of one of the many ways this game is brilliantly balanced. Another is the castle layouts. Each time you die, your next character explores a whole new layout. Unless, of course, you agree to give a percentage of your gold to one of the characters in front of the castle so that he can keep the layout the same! Finally, you do not get to choose your character and customize them complete. Instead, when you begin a new character, you can choose from one of three, each with their own unique traits and class and magic. This may sound like a bad thing, but it often instead leads you to discover the use of a class you have not used much, and how to deal with some of the more difficult traits in the game.  All in all, this is a game that will continue to draw you back death after death, Sometimes your best character will meet an untimely death, and sometimes your worst will make you the richest hero alive. Never knowing what will happen next is half the fun, and the further you get the less predictable things become, even as more abilities become available to you. While this game is quite challenging, I would recommend it to anyone, as it is a top-of-the-line model when it comes to games of any kind.

Rogue Legacy is an excellent 2D platformer that revolves around the unique generations mechanic. Unlike normal roguelikes, which can lack depth due to lack of character progression, Rogue Legacy allows the player to progress his character's family generation after generation. Each run through the castle will be completely different from the last, simply because each gero is totally different.  Humor is, well, funny, if sometimes politically incorrect and sometimes childish. Easter-egg-esque features (changes in the loading screen to reflect current character traits, changes in in-game text and dialogue to reflect traits like Dyslexia) keep anyone playing or watching entertained, and a collection of positive and negative traits powerful enough to be useful, but not game-breaking, ensure an interesting experience for hours.  The game's story is surprisingly sober in the midst of all this, and though it's simple (presented in a series of journal entires found throughout the castle) it has the desired effect. It periodically hints at where to go next ('Now on to the Jungle!') in case the player is lost, and it achieves a surprisingly emotional impact at its conclusion.

This may be a game of perfection. I highly recommend it to anyone as it is a solid game for any player. This is a rogue-like, randomly generated dungeon crawler that forces you to fight your way through rooms of enemies, solve puzzles to open chests, and defeat bosses in four sections of the castle.  The beauty of this game is that death is accepted, when you die you simply choose one of three randomly generated characters, cash in on the gold you found, and fight through another castle. At first you are likely to die many times without many kills, but as you learn the enemies and buy upgrades you will slowly find the game getting easier. Learning enemies is essential in this game. They will start out simple, but as you progress they get more difficult with more health, more shots fired, or new variations on enemies previously fought.  A good chunk of this game is about fighting to find treasure. You will mostly collect gold which can be used to buy more health, mana, armor; or you can buy new classes to play as, have a better chance to land a critical hit, or make your spells the hardest hitting in the land. You will also find armor and 'runes' (which will add more variety and strategy to each playthrough) in which you must purchase with the gold you earn.  As you select a new class to play you will find random traits your characters may have. Some may only be able to see in black and white, some may be flexible (allowing them to change direction mid-swing), or maybe they have terrible memories (good luck navigating without a map!). The spells you can cast are random as well, some spanning from a simple projectile, to a giant sword wall to keep enemies away.  Absolutely amazing, worth every penny! Controls are tight, graphics are that of the Super Nintendo era, with a great polish. The music can get a bit redundant, but never takes away from the game as most the time you will find yourself focused on not dying. I have heard there may be a secret room to take away from that problem, if you happen to find it, may I recommend 'The Fish and the Whale'. ENJOY!

Rogue Legacy is a roguelike hack-n-slash platformer with very challenging gameplay, that rewards mastery of movement controls above all else. However, every run through the shifting castle dungeon gets you a little further- any gold you earn can be used by your next character to purchase upgrades and gear. The game has a sort of heritage system, in each run you choose a child of your previous character, who can be one of several classes and may have any number of beneficial, harmful or completely benign medical conditions, another element of randomization atop the expected ones: randomized dungeon layout and loot. Character customization is extensive, with various gear setups of weapons and armor, and skill runes that add things like extra jumps or air dashes. I died many, many times over the course of my playthrough, especially during the very difficult (perhaps even cheap) boss fights, but unlike some roguelikes the game never really punishes you for that. You're even able to 'lock' the castle and reenter the same layout as your next character, expiditing your progress to say, a boss room. I found myself addicted to the game, wanting to go on 'just one more run' to get another upgrade before moving on to something else. The game has decent music and a charming art style as well, which clashes nicely with its rather grim lore. The game delivered strongly on that 'what's in the next room?!' factor that I love about these sorts of games, including action roguelikes like Diablo and its derivities. Rogue Legacy was persistently entertaining throughout and I can recommend it to most, even those who would normally shy away from a roguelike.

Starts out really addicting, but at a certain point it becomes a grind for money in which to level up your character. Unlike other roguelikes that introduces new powerups and abilities as you progress, your character traits and abilities are set before entering the dungeons, castles, and outdoor areas. New abilities and armor upgrades can be found littered throughout the areas in the form of challenges and chest drops. Abilities come in the form of Runes and armor upgrades drop from certain chests.   While it's a good encentive to replay the game over and over again to find all upgrades, it unfortunately requires money to equip them, which increases in cost after each purchase.  Along the way you'll pick up some passive powerups such as ones that gives you more money drops or another that lets the player walk on spikes, but they rarely change up the gameplay and is active only on the current playthrough until found again on other playthroughs. Majority of the time you're using your sword to attack with the addition of a side weapon that uses MP points, very much like Castlevania games.   Enemies often repeat thoughtout each of the form areas. Their size, color, and health are different, usually increasing for the difficulty. The boss enemies of each area are large and require a lot of damage. While they're fun and challenging to fight, you'll spend most of your time to grind even before attempting to take them on again. And after defeating them the first time, the next time you want to take them on, they are stronger, faster, and have different movements. The game also forces the player to use a set character, but are given unlimited tries. In my opinion it's a poor choice to not allow the player to take on the original version of the boss. It makes most playthrough a money hunt and regular enemy whacking game.   Rogue Legacy is worthy of your time if you enjoy rogue-likes, but there are better ones out that reward the player better and have better incentives to keep playing.

Rogue Legacy is a necessary evolution of the rogue-like genre. In most rogue-likes, the goal is to survive as long as you can and progress as much as you can. Upon death, all progression is lost. Rogue Legacy may seem to at first follow the familiar formula, but its formula is more familial than familiar. The ability to pass down your upgrades and items to your next life allows for a unique progression, in which each life can serve a unique purpose, instead of being a randomly reiterated version of the past life. Every death, while it restarts your dungeon-crawl, enables you to explore further in your next life. This formula is much more engaging to me than your typical rogue-like.

The gameplay is difficult and occasionally frustrating, but in a fun way.   The music is superb. It adds just the right atmosphere without being so imposing that it gets old. I've heard the intro to the main castle music probably 500 times and it still brings a smaile to my face.   The character traits offer a lot of diversity and the random dungeon layouts allow the player to experience the unfamiliar exploration phase of the game every life (unless they buy an upgrade that will let them keep the immediately prior layout for a large fraction of the next run-through's gold). I don't normally like the game mechanic of grinding for randomized loot, but the way it's integrated into Rogue Legacy makes it a charming and goofy quirk of the game's premise rather than just a rule that forces you to grind for grinding's sake as it is usually emplyed in games. That is a feat.  Bottom Line: Rogue Legacy is just plain fun. It's on par with the best of the sidescrollers of the 8- and 16-bit eras while being fresh and quirky in its own way.

Rogue Legacy is an amazing rogue-like game, where dying doesn't mean a full reset of the game, as money is kept until the start of another playthrough. This feature means that the choices you make between playthroughs affects the way you play the game greatly, and makes you put some thought into investments, rather than buying whatever you can afford. Overall, a great game, and I recommend it to anyone out there who likes rogue-like games.
